Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
On 9/4/21, there was an incident where Youth A had to be restrained. Youth A was
restrained by Staff 3. After the restraints, Youth A reported Staff 3 had his knee on
his back and was bending and twisting Youth A's arm. Youth A is now complaining
that his arm hurts. There were other staff present that reported that this did not
occur.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Administrator 1 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the
facility on 9/9/2021. He provided the requested paperwork including the safety plan
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

for Youth A. He denied witnessing the incident but speaking to Youth A the next day
and then making the report to DHHS. Youth A told him he has “issues with Staff 3”
and Youth A “bragged about wanting to get Staff 3 into trouble”. He reported Staff 3
as the identified staff and Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 as witnesses to the incident. Staff
3 has worked at the facility for the past nine plus years Administrator 1 reported the
technique used in the restraint was approved and taught to all staff. He also reported
“if a youth goes to the ground, staff are to disengage and help them back to their
feet. Two staff will engage in a Team Control which involves staff on each side of the
youth holding their arm and shoulder with their leg in front of the youth. Staff’s hips
are to be next to the youth’s hip for support”. He was asked about the delay in
medical treatment for Youth A and reported a wellness check was completed by the
supervisor on site and it was determined that medical care was not needed at the
time. He reported staff witnessed Youth A engage in several actions such as
punching and pounding on a glass window and door to playing basketball following
the incident. He reported these actions supported staff’s decision to not provide
outside medical care at the time.
I interviewed Administrator 2 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the
facility on 9/9/2021. He reported being aware of the incident but not present at the
time of the incident. He took Youth A to the doctor’s office on Tuesday, September
7th. Youth A told the doctor that he had pain in his left shoulder and left arm. The
doctor asked him about the marks on his face and Youth A said the “marks were
caused by him picking pimples”. The x-rays were negative, and Youth A received a
tetanus shot for the abrasions.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the
facility on 9/9/2021. She reported entering the incident and observing Staff 1 and
Staff 3 engaged in a Team Control with each staff on a different side of Youth A,
holding his arm with one hand on his shoulder. Youth A was “cursing, spiting and
threatening to kill Staff 3 if the staff did not let go of him”. She attempted to
deescalate Youth A and eventually switched out with Staff 3 because he appeared
to be the focus of Youth A’s anger and Youth A threatened to get Staff 3 fired. Youth
A kept trying to drop his weight and the two staff would release him and help him
back to his feet. She denied the allegations of Youth A’s arm being twisted or a staff
placing their knee in his back. She reported the behavior management techniques
she observed were appropriate. Youth A threatened her with being fired because
she didn’t take him to the doctor when he reported his arm was broken. She
reported he finally calmed down and he left the area with her. A few minutes after
this, Youth A started walking around campus and ended up at the administration
building. She reported he was “pounding on the door and windows in a very violent
manner with both arms” after saying his arm was broken. She reported his actions
with his arms lead her to believe that he didn’t need medical care at the time. She
told Youth A at the time that there didn’t appear to be anything wrong with is arm
because of his actions. Supervisor 1 reported she is trained to observe the reported
injury and determine if additional medical help is needed and believing that it was
not.
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

I interviewed Staff 1 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility on
9/9/2021. He reported being part of the incident with Youth A and described the
incident stating, “Youth A was having a good day up until we went to the gym. While
in the gym he asked to go back to the house to get his water bottle and I told him
that he could just use the drinking fountain in the gym. Youth A said he would go
mobile (described when a youth leaves the area without permission and staff must
follow the youth) and left the gym with Staff 3 following him.” Staff 1 followed behind
them and when he caught up to them, Youth A was attempting to climb through a
window into the house. He initiated a Team Control which he described as
Supervisor 1 had described after Staff 3 positioned himself to keep Youth A from
climbing through the window. Youth A became very aggressive and began to
threaten and spit on Staff 3. This led to the restraint of Youth A. Staff 1 reported
“Staff 3 had Youth A’s arm too high for my comfort and I told him to lower his arm
which he did immediately”. Youth A began to say Staff 3 was twisting his arm at this
time and increased his threats towards Staff 3. He reported Youth A dropped his
weight causing the three of them to move forward with Youth A going to the ground.
Both staff released Youth A at this time before helping him back to his feet. They
attempted to escort Youth A to a “safer area without rough ground” but during the
escort, Youth A continued to be very aggressive and dropped his weight again. Staff
1 reported, Supervisor 1 came onto the scene at this time and swapped positions
with Staff 3. Youth A walked to a bench with Supervisor 1 and told staff to call an
ambulance because he believed his arm was broken. Staff 1 reported going to get
water for Youth A at which time, Youth A left the bench and went to the maintenance
shed where he began to pound on the door with both hands. Youth A then walked to
the Administration building where he began to pound on the windows and door with
his arms. He reported Supervisor 1 let him into the building and he calmed down but
was still demanding that staff call child protective services. Staff 1 reported Youth A
has been having issues with Staff 3 and doesn’t like him. He also reported this was
over Staff 3 confronting him for being on an inappropriate website during school and
taking the computer away. He reported the restraint and behavior management
techniques used were appropriate and denied any twisting of his arm or a knee in
his back. He reported the marks on Youth A’s face were caused by the dirt and
rough ground when he dropped his weight and went to the ground. He also reported
there were other youth at the administration building for a work session, but he is
unsure if they observed the incident. He identified three staff (Staff 2, Staff 4, and
Staff 6) as staff with the other youth and possible witnesses. Staff 1 reported
observing Youth A using his hurt arm to play basketball and was throwing a ball in a
game at the house following the incident.
I interviewed Youth A in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility
on 9/9/2021. He began the interview by reporting an incident with Staff 3 prior to the
restraint. He reported Staff 3 came to his room one hour before the incident and
said, “I’m not playing with you today and will slap the shit out of you”. He also
reported Staff 3 blocked his exit from the room and he responded by saying he only
wanted to read his book. He reported Youth B was witness to this exchange. Youth
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

A reported forgetting his water bottle in the house as the underlying reason he asked
to return to the house for the water bottle during the time in the gym. He left the gym
after being told he could not go back to the house. He reported being told by Staff 3
that “no one was going to let me in the house” so he went to the side and opened
the window. Youth A reported, “as I opened the window, Staff 3 grabbed my arm and
slammed me”. He reported, Staff 3 “wrapped my arm around my neck and when he
slammed me on the ground, he had his knee in my back pushing down and pulling
my arm behind me”. Youth A reported hearing a “popping noise” and he began to
scream. He reported Staff 1 came to help after being slammed to the ground by Staff
3. Staff 1 told him to “chill out” several times before telling Staff 3 to let him up. Staff
3 let him up only to slam him on the ground a second time. He reported landing on
his face when Staff 3 slammed him to the ground. He also reported other youth were
watching him at this time but was unable to identify who these youth were. He
reported Staff 3 “slammed me four more times before Supervisor 1 showed up and
switched out with Staff 3”. He told Supervisor 1 prior to the switch that Staff 3 was
attempting to break his arm. He reported having a “panic attack and not being able
to breath” while sitting on the bench with Supervisor 1. He reported “Youth B
witnessed the whole incident” and Staff 4 was also present. Youth A reported he
was unable to move his arm the rest of the day following the incident and did not
participate in basketball or any other activities.
I interviewed Youth B in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility
on 9/9/2021. He reported living in the same house as Youth A but did not report any
awareness of any situation between Youth A and Staff 3 in the house prior to the
group going to the gym. He gave a similar report to the situation with the water
bottle, and he observed the restraint from the gym. He reported seeing a knee on
Youth A’s back but was unable to identify who’s knee it was. At first, he reported
observing staff slam Youth A to the ground but changed his story to only observing
Staff 3 grab Youth A’s arm. He also reported Staff 1, Staff 3, and Staff 5 were
present. Youth A was in the gym after the incident “shooting hoops” and later playing
a ball game in the house.
I interviewed Youth C in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility
on 9/9/2021. He reported living in the same house as Youth A and reported only
witnessing Youth A “drop” from the gym. He further explained “drop” meant Youth A
dropped his weight while being restrained and staff released him. Youth A appeared
to be struggling with the restraint. Four staff were present at the time of the restraint
including Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Supervisor 1. He also reported observing
Youth A’s arm and stated, “his arm turned purple”. He reported observing staff bend
Youth A’s arm and being told by staff that he should not say anything. He was
unable to identify the staff that told him this. He reported talking to all staff and
having them tell him that Youth A’s arm was alright.
I interviewed Staff 2 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility on
9/9/2021. He reported being with another group of youth in front of the
Administration building when he heard Youth A screaming. He observed Youth A in
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

a standing restraint with Staff 1 and Staff 3. He never observed Youth A on the
ground and what he observed of the restraint was appropriate. He described the
action staff are to take when a youth drops their weight during a restraint in a similar
manner to the other descriptions by staff.
I interviewed Staff 3 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist at the facility on
9/9/2021. He reported expectations were given to all the youth prior to the activity in
the gym. Youth A left the gym after Staff 1 told him he could not leave to go back
and get his water bottle. Staff 3 reported following Youth A to the house and to the
window Youth A attempted to enter. He stood near Youth A to keep him from going
through the window to which Youth A responded with a “fighting position and spiting
on me”. Staff 1 was present and both placed Youth A in a team control position. He
gave a similar description of the actions of both staff and Youth A as described by
Staff 1. He reported Youth A spit on him several times and was threating to kill him if
not released. Youth A dropped his weight twice causing him to go to the ground at
which time they disengaged. He reported trying to escort Youth A to a safer location
before Supervisor 1 switched position with him. He denied engaging in a restraint
while Youth A was on the ground and never putting his knee in Youth A’s back. He
reported Youth A went to the ground twice after dropping his weight which caused
the staff to also fall but not on top of Youth A. Staff 1 informed him that he was
holding Youth A’s arm too high of a position, so he lowered the arm at which time,
Youth A began to say his arm was broken. He reported he left the situation but was
called for assistance to help Staff 1 after Youth A went “mobile” again. Once arriving
back on the scene, he found Staff 1 and Youth A near the Administration building
with Youth A banging on the windows and door. Staff 3 reported Youth A was
complaining of a broken arm while using this arm to bang on the windows and door.
Following the incident, Staff 3 observed Youth A playing basketball in the gym and
“dribbling with both hands”. He reported following the behavior management
techniques and engaging in an appropriate restraint.
I interviewed Staff 4 by phone on 9/14/2021. She stated, “I didn’t see enough to
be helpful”. She reported being near the administration building when Youth D said,
“Youth A was tackled by Staff 3”. She also reported not being able to hear anything
because they were using lawn mowers at the time. She reported observing Staff 3
laying on top of Youth A and after calling for “emergency procedures, Staff 1 came
on the scene and placed Youth A into a “team control”.
I interviewed Staff 5 by phone on 9/14/2021. She reported being the third staff
with the youth in the gym. Staff 1 and Staff 3 left to deal with Youth A and after
getting the emergency call, she began the process of escorting the other youth to
the house. She reported several other youth attempted to go into the hallway to
watch but she redirected them back into the gym to pick up the basketballs. She
reported never witnessing Youth A or the two staff on the ground. She also reported
never observing the twisting of Youth A’s arm or a knee in his back. She reported
observing Youth A getting his arm free during the standing restraint and attempting
to hit Staff 3.
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

I interviewed Staff 3 by phone on 9/14/2021. He confirmed that Youth A did take a
swing at him and spit on him as the reasons to initiate the restraint. He also reported
Staff 5 observed Youth A take a swing at him while Youth A was being held in the
team control position. He reported not sharing Youth A tried to swing at him during
the first interview because “I thought you already knew about it from reading the
incident report”.
I interviewed Staff 6 by phone on 9/16/2021. She reported being with another
group of youth at the administration building during the time the incident with Youth
A took place. She heard Youth A yell and turned around to see what was happening.
It looked like only Staff 3 was present with Youth A before Staff 1 showed up. Both
staff were standing next to Youth A when he went to the ground. She reported “it
looked like Staff 3 was also on the ground, but I couldn’t tell if he was on top of
Youth A or not”.
I interviewed Youth D in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist by video
conference on 9/20/2021. He reported being involved in a work session at the
administration building when he observed Youth A coming out of the house. He also
reported operating a lawn mower at the time and his focus was more on the lawn
mower than the incident. He reported not being able to identify the two staff but
reported observing “Youth A was on the ground with staff trying to hold him still”. He
denied observing Staff 3 on top of Youth A while Youth A was on the ground. He
reported being confused about Youth A yelling his arm was broken when he
observed Youth A playing basketball later in the day.
I interviewed Youth A in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist by video
conferencing on 9/30/2021. He gave the same information that he reported in the
first interview. He also reported the injury to his face was caused when he was
“slammed on the ground”. He reported being on his stomach while on the ground
with Staff 3 having a knee in his back.
I interviewed Staff 1 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist by video
conferencing on 9/30/2021. He reported the same information given during the first
interview. He reported both Youth A and Staff 3 were standing when he reached
them, and Staff 3 was standing between Youth A and the window. He reported there
was “not enough time for Staff 3 to put Youth A on the ground” before he showed up.
He reported the marks on Youth A’s face occurred “when he dropped his weight”. He
reported the reason for the restraint was Youth A’s “risky behavior” of trying to get
through the window. He denied observing Youth A try to hit Staff 3.
I interviewed Staff 3 in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist by video
conferencing on 9/30/2021. He reported never touching Youth A until Youth A
“stepped back in a fighting stance and took a swing”. He gave two different reports
about the location of Staff 1 when Youth A attempted to hit him. He first reported
Staff 1 was present and then reported not knowing where Staff 1 was at the time. He
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

described his reaction to the swing, “I stopped the swing with my right arm when I
put a bear hug on his arm which was across my chest and his arm was under my
arm”. He denied placing Youth A in a prone position and reported the only time
Youth A was in a prone position was when he dropped his weight and went to the
ground. He denied observing any marks on Youth A’s face and reported an
understanding that if a youth is spitting on a staff the youth can be restrained.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
I reviewed the video footage of Youth A playing basketball and using both arms
several hours after the restraint and Youth A stating his arm was broken.
I reviewed the HR documents for Staff 3. There was no disciplinary action located
within the file.
I reviewed the Residential Initial Treatment Plan for Youth A. This document is dated
7/7/21 and covers a period of 6/9/21 to 7/7/21. Goals identified included learning to
cope with his emotions in a safe and productive manner and understanding
consequences relative to negative behavior patterns under the Peer/Adult social
relationships domain.
I reviewed the documents from the doctor’s visit by Youth A on 9/7/21. The
document is dated 9/7/21 and identifies the reason for the visit as “Shoulder Pain”.
Also identified as “Current Visit Problem(s)/problem list” are injury due to altercation,
elbow abrasion, muscle strain of left scapular region and strain of left elbow. “Plan of
Care” has instructions of “Ice, Gentle Rom. Keep abrasion clean and dry, report
signs of infection, recheck 2-3 days if any problems. Tetanus was given today.
Please update your records.” (there was no mention of the marks on Youth A’s face)
I reviewed the incident report of the restraint that occurred on 9/4/21.This document
lists staff involved as Staff 1 and Staff 3. It also lists the following staff as witnesses,
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 5. Youth A is listed as the Youth A involved. This report
presents the same as the statements by Staff 1 and Staff 3 reported. This document
states “Youth A turned to Staff 3 in an aggressive, challenging position and tried to
take a swing”. It is also documented that staff completed a “wellness check” on
Youth A. It is documented, “Youth A complained his left arm hurt but was able to
move it and some scratches on the side of his face”.
I reviewed the medical procedures for the facility. This document states “if a medical
situation occurs that appears to be an emergency, take all necessary steps to
ensure the safety, comfort and proper care of the student. Then contact the Resident
Manager / Supervisor in Charge advise of the emergency and act on their
instructions.”
I reviewed the behavior management policy/procedure. The policy states staff are to
disengage in a restraint if a youth drops weight and reengage once they are
235 SOUTH GRAND AVENUE  PO BOX 30037
 LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/mdhhs  517-373-3740

standing again if needed. Staff can help bring the youth back up to his knees or a
standing position without the use of force.
I reviewed the “Non-Violent Crisis Intervention” manual used by the facility for the
physical management of youth.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child’s behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident’s treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: Although there was not consistent evidence to support Staff 3
had his knee on Youth A’s back and twisted Youth A's arm, the
facility is found in non-compliance as Staff 3 did not use proper
restraint technique.
Technical Assistance:
The facility followed their protocol in response to Youth A
reporting he was injured. However, it is recommended the
facility protocol be updated to include a medical professional
assessment be obtained if a youth reports an injury.
Additionally, the facility’s nurse recently resigned. The facility is
aware this is a required position and will continue to work to
replace the position.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0214007 dated 03/11/21, CAP approved 03/15/21
SIR 2021C0207017 dated 05/24/21, CAP approved 08/10/21
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, a review of the Behavior Management
Philosophy and Procedures document found the following statement “Staff cannot
utilize physical management to address behavioral issues, only if there is an
imminent threat of danger to an individual or significant and dangerous property
damage (a student is attempting to break glass).”
APPLICABLE RULE
JRM 610 Youth Restraint
General Guidance
Per Emergency CCI Rules 3(1), facility staff may only restrain a
youth to prevent serious injury to the youth, self-injury or injury to

others.
ANALYSIS:
The facility’s policy is in direct violation of their Residential
Foster Care Juvenile Justice (RFCJJ) contract. The contract
refers to JRM 610 which does not allow for a restraint to occur
for
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS
Staff 3 did not demonstrate the abilities to perform his job duties.
INVESTIGATION:
During a case conference on September 30, 2021, the DHHS worker reported her
investigation resulted in a preponderance of evidence.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position
assigned.
ANALYSIS: Staff 3’s was substantiated for child physical abuse.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
